reviews.review_msg: The worst prof in HSCI faculty at SFU, if not the worst prof in the entire university
Interesting class if you liked content of HSCI 319. But be aware that it is not an easy class. A lot of readings and writing, and you need to be somewhat skilled in philosophy.
Nice prof. Be prepared to read. The topics are confusing so get help.

Diego pushes you to think outside of the box. His tests were fair, he provided great feedback on the final paper and the readings he chose applied to other HSCI classes. Yes, you have to put the work into his class; the reality is we are not 'purchasing' our BA, we have to work hard for it.

Well, other 319 proff is said to be way easier and that is one good reason to avoid Diego.  A LOT of readings, all tests are essay form plus there is another big essay, because of this you won't get your grades until very end of the course.  On a good note he is pretty funny, approachable and his lectures are interesting.

319 is a difficult course, especially if you are not the best writer. Diego tries to make the material interesting. However, the large amount of readings towards the end if semester (about 3 - 4 a week) make it difficult to stay up to date on material. This course requires close analysis of text, which is difficult when you have 4 reading per week.

hard marking, 1 term paper which he marks. Topics were really boring and useless for me but some ppl enjoyed them. Diego is a nice guy but I felt he can't teach as he overcomplicated simple topics. Slides are not useful b/c he wants you to attend lecture (where he explains the readings) which is also not very useful. Ask the TA for help. Ends late.
